title: Exhibit: The Perfect Sea Mural
description:
Date: September 22, 2021

Members of the South Shore Artists Group created an engaging and interactive mural entitled "The Perfect Sea" to educate children and adults about the sea and its ecology; in particular, how pollution affects sea life in our local waters.

The exhibition will be on display at the Lenape Gallery at the Conference House Park Visitors Center through the end of the year.

Free admission.

All current COVID-19 protocols to be followed

Start time: 10:00 am

title: Exhibit: Fire and Tide - Terra Marine Inn: A Brief History of Huguenot Park, Staten Island
description:
Date: September 22, 2021

Explore a bit of Staten Island's past and history.

The Fire and Tide exhibition explores the history of the former turn of the century Terra Marine Inn. This hotel was a wonderful piece of Staten Island gilded past. The exhibit combines history and original artwork focusing on the bygone location.

Free admission. Exhibit on display through December.

All COVID-19 protocols to be followed.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (917) 417-6817

title: Watercolor Workshops
description:
Date: September 22, 2021

Join us for a watercolor painting workshop series in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Kalila Adbur-Razzaq will teach you how to draw and paint using nature as your inspiration. Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. About the artist:Kalila Abdur-Razzaq was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. She recently graduated Purchase College with a concentration in painting and a minor in Art History. Her preferred mediums are oil, watercolor, and silkscreen. As of 2021, Abdur-Razzaq is included in three permanent installations. The most recent is a commission by The Colored Girls Museum of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Start time: 3:00 pm

End time: 5:00 pm

title: Ready to Rumba: Celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month
description:
Date: September 22, 2021

Join us in partnership with Ballroom Basix USA to celebrate the start of Hispanic Heritage Month and the re-opening of Thomas Jefferson Recreation Center with free dance classes for the community. This will be a two-day event with non-competitive Ballroom and Latin dances where we will teach: Merengue, Bachata, Salsa, and more.

This event is free and open to the public, but space is limited.

To RSVP, please email Ruth.Mendin@parks.nyc.gov.

Know before you go:

  • Covid vaccination required, for those who are eligible, to enter the recreation center to participate in activities.
  • Please wear a mask regardless of vaccination status.
  • All individuals should maintain social distancing of six feet during programming, regardless of vaccination status.
  • Wash your hands before attending a program.
  • Stay home if you are sick.

Start time: 5:00 pm

End time: 7:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 860-1383

Location: Thomas Jefferson Recreation Center (in Thomas Jefferson Park)

title: 'Troubled Like the Restless Sea': Frederick Douglass and the 'Profusion of Luxury' in Early America
description:
Date: September 22, 2021

By Dr. R. Ruthie Dibble, Curator of The Chipstone Foundation and Dr. Tiffany Momon, Assistant Professor at Sewanee: The University of the South.

Over 150 years after the publication of My Bondage and My Freedom, Frederick Douglass’s rhetorical genius still offers new insights into American art and history. Co-curators Drs. Ruthie Dibble and Tiffany Momon illuminate how a passage from Douglass’s autobiography became the basis of a collaborative curatorial intervention at the Milwaukee Art Museum that explores the troubled status of luxury goods in early America. Douglass’s words, along with those of other writers who bore witness to the injustices that shaped luxury goods in early America, offer new ways to think about the intersections of slavery, settler colonialism, and the “profusion of luxury” that filled many American homes in the 1800s. Prompted by Douglas’s observation that luxury goods of enslaver households were “Troubled, like the restless sea,” the speakers will explore how undercurrents of power and profit shaped iconic examples of luxury goods, from the first porcelain made in America to the ornate furniture crafted in New York City for Cuban plantations.

Register online

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 7:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 304-9422

Location: Virtual/Online Workshop

title: Camera Obscura at Dyckman Farmhouse Museum
description:
Date: September 23, 2021

Gibson + Recoder: Obscurus Projectum

Across its long history, the camera obscura has been an artistic tool, a philosophical device, a scientific implement. Each function has made the camera obscura an analog of something: the eye, human consciousness, the “outside” world itself (Gibson and Recoder call it “the earliest projection of the world, or simply world projection”). The renewed interest in the camera obscura evidenced by exhibitions like this one, and the persistence with which some filmmakers and critics work to sustain analogue moving image media, are sometimes dismissed as mere nostalgia, or contrariness for its own sake, or fetishism of technologies that have been rendered obsolete by digital. Obscurus Projectum suggests another, deeper, reason for the ongoing appeal of the analogue in the so-called digital millennium: rather than alienating us with a cryptic interior that has no “room” for us, camera obscuras – as models of analogue image-making technology in general – admit us, let us in. They make real space for our bodies rather than a virtual space we cannot inhabit. They are part of the physical world we live in. Analog and digital media both make images, of course, but the former also appeals to our tactile sense, and thus answers our desire for physical connection with our world and with those objects and other bodies with whom we share our rooms. (Jonathan Walley)

This program is made possible by the New York City Artist Corps.

Gibson + Recoder have exhibited their celebrated expanded cinema performances and installations at the Museum Kunstpalast Düsseldorf, M HKA, Serralves Foundation, EYE Film Museum, REDCAT, Mad. Sq. Art, and Ballroom Marfa. Their works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney Museum of American Art, Academy Museum of Motion Pictures, and Memorial Art Gallery. They live and work in New York. www.gibsonrecoder.com

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 2:00 pm

title: River Project: Live From the Field
description:

Wildlife thrives all over NYC, especially in HRPK's waters! Tune into @HudsonRiverPark's Instagram Live for an insider’s look into the Park's Estuarine Sanctuary as we study environmental DNA, analyze microplastics, sample fish populations and so much more!

HRPK's River Project conducts research and offers hands-on environmental education and scientific programming with the purpose of communicating the ecological importance of the Park’s 400-acre Estuarine Sanctuary. Dedicated to community engagement, stewardship and learning, the River Project offers at-home STEM activities, tours of marine-biology stations and other educational resources to support scientific understanding of the Lower Hudson Estuary.

title: Concert: Camille Thurman Quartet
description:
Date: September 23, 2021

Equally adept as a saxophonist and a singer, and recognized for her compositional abilities as well, Camille Thurman has earned accolades. Her rich sax sound has been compared to Joe Henderson and Dexter Gordon, while her vocal approach—including an impressive scatting ability—has been classified alongside those of Ella Fitzgerald and Betty Carter. In recent years she has shared stages with notable figures like George Coleman, Roy Haynes, Dianne Reeves, Wynton Marsalis, Jack DeJohnette, , Jon Hendricks, Harry Connick Jr., Jon Batiste, Diana Krall, Patti LaBelle, Gladys Knight, Chaka Khan, Louis Hayes, Alicia Keys, Jill Scott and Erykah Badu, among many others. Her acclaimed work with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra included a recent, striking feature on their big band arrangement of John Coltrane's A Love Supreme. With an opening set by percussion great Baba Don Babatunde.

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 8:30 pm

title: Gallery Talk: Gibson + Recoder
description:
Date: September 23, 2021

Gibson + Recoder: Obscurus Projectum

Across its long history, the camera obscura has been an artistic tool, a philosophical device, a scientific implement. Each function has made the camera obscura an analog of something: the eye, human consciousness, the “outside” world itself (Gibson and Recoder call it “the earliest projection of the world, or simply world projection”). The renewed interest in the camera obscura evidenced by exhibitions like this one, and the persistence with which some filmmakers and critics work to sustain analogue moving image media, are sometimes dismissed as mere nostalgia, or contrariness for its own sake, or fetishism of technologies that have been rendered obsolete by digital. Obscurus Projectum suggests another, deeper, reason for the ongoing appeal of the analogue in the so-called digital millennium: rather than alienating us with a cryptic interior that has no “room” for us, camera obscuras – as models of analogue image-making technology in general – admit us, let us in. They make real space for our bodies rather than a virtual space we cannot inhabit. They are part of the physical world we live in. Analog and digital media both make images, of course, but the former also appeals to our tactile sense, and thus answers our desire for physical connection with our world and with those objects and other bodies with whom we share our rooms. (Jonathan Walley)

Via Zoom

This program is made possible by the New York City Artist Corps.

Gibson + Recoder have exhibited their celebrated expanded cinema performances and installations at the Museum Kunstpalast Düsseldorf, M HKA, Serralves Foundation, EYE Film Museum, REDCAT, Mad. Sq. Art, and Ballroom Marfa. Their works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney Museum of American Art, Academy Museum of Motion Pictures, and Memorial Art Gallery. They live and work in New York. www.gibsonrecoder.com

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 7:00 pm

title: Movies Under the Stars: The Express
description:
Date: September 23, 2021

Join NYC Parks and New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for this free film!

The Express (2008)

This drama is based on the life of Syracuse University football player Ernie Davis, the first African American to win the Heisman Trophy. This inspiring film explores civil rights topics, such as racism, discrimination and athletics. It was the film debut of Chadwick Boseman (Black Panther) and stars Rob Brown (Treme) in the title role, Dennis Quaid (Everybody’s All-American) and Charles S. Dutton (Longmire). Rated PG

Know Before You Go

title: Movies Under the Stars: The Wizard of Oz
description:
Date: September 23, 2021

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film!

Grab a blanket and come enjoy a movie in a neighborhood park or playground! This summer, NYC Parks will host family-friendly movie showings across the five boroughs. Movies begin at dusk. You should arrive before 8:00 p.m. to get your spot. This event is FREE and open to the public, but seating is limited. Reservations are not taken.

The Wizard of Oz

A young farm girl and her little dog are magically transported into the enchanted land of Oz via a Kansas tornado. As they travel down Oz's Yellow Brick Road to find the Wizard and ask him to send them home, they encounter a wonderful, funny, terrifying and, ultimately, enlightening group of characters, human and otherwise. Rated G.

Know Before You Go:

title: Camera Obscura at Dyckman Farmhouse Museum
description:
Date: September 24, 2021

Gibson + Recoder: Obscurus Projectum

Across its long history, the camera obscura has been an artistic tool, a philosophical device, a scientific implement. Each function has made the camera obscura an analog of something: the eye, human consciousness, the “outside” world itself (Gibson and Recoder call it “the earliest projection of the world, or simply world projection”). The renewed interest in the camera obscura evidenced by exhibitions like this one, and the persistence with which some filmmakers and critics work to sustain analogue moving image media, are sometimes dismissed as mere nostalgia, or contrariness for its own sake, or fetishism of technologies that have been rendered obsolete by digital. Obscurus Projectum suggests another, deeper, reason for the ongoing appeal of the analogue in the so-called digital millennium: rather than alienating us with a cryptic interior that has no “room” for us, camera obscuras – as models of analogue image-making technology in general – admit us, let us in. They make real space for our bodies rather than a virtual space we cannot inhabit. They are part of the physical world we live in. Analog and digital media both make images, of course, but the former also appeals to our tactile sense, and thus answers our desire for physical connection with our world and with those objects and other bodies with whom we share our rooms. (Jonathan Walley)

This program is made possible by the New York City Artist Corps.

Gibson + Recoder have exhibited their celebrated expanded cinema performances and installations at the Museum Kunstpalast Düsseldorf, M HKA, Serralves Foundation, EYE Film Museum, REDCAT, Mad. Sq. Art, and Ballroom Marfa. Their works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney Museum of American Art, Academy Museum of Motion Pictures, and Memorial Art Gallery. They live and work in New York. www.gibsonrecoder.com

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 2:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 304-9422

title: Greenbelt Nature Hike: New Section of Red Trail
description:
Date: September 24, 2021

Join us for a hike in the heart of the Greenbelt, as we transverse the newly aligned section of the Red Trail. We will enter a scenic deep hollow which was the place of an orchard long ago. This hike is approximately 90 minutes and has some hills.

Register on Eventbrite

Registration: By registering for this event, you confirm that you have read our COVID-19 precautions and media consent. The event is free but registration is required.

Gear: Wear clothes you don’t mind getting dirty - long, light-colored pants are preferred. Closed-toed shoes (sneakers or boots) are required. Please bring water, sunscreen, and insect repellent.

Cancellation: This program may be canceled if registration is too low, or if there is inclement weather predicted on the day of the event. Please ensure that we have your correct information so that we can contact you in the event of a cancellation. As we receive cancellations, names will be added from the waitlist. If you know you will be unable to attend, please cancel your registration by email at sigreenbelteducation@gmail.com or by phone at (718) 351-3450 ext. 0, so we can fill the reservation.

Media Consent: By registering for this program, you are agreeing to have your image used in promotional materials by the Greenbelt Conservancy, including but not limited to, photographs and video. If you choose not to give consent, please let us know by emailing us at sigreenbelteducation@gmail.com before the event.

COVID-19 Precautions:

All visitors and staff must wear a mask during the entire event.

Masks and hand sanitizer will be available.

All equipment will be sanitized before and after the event. (will be included if we are using equipment)

By participating in this event you are acknowledging that you and your guests have not experienced a fever, not tested positive for COVID-19, and have not been exposed to anyone with COVID-19 within 14 days of the event. Should you develop symptoms after registration, please cancel your registration by emailing sigreenbelteducation@gmail.com.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 351-3450

Location: Greenbelt Nature Center (in Blood Root Valley)

title: Watercolor Workshop
description:
Date: September 24, 2021

Join us for a watercolor painting workshop series in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Kenneth Fitzpatrick will teach you how to draw and paint using nature as your inspiration. Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.For your comfort, bring a mat or chair.About the artist:Kenneth Fitzpatrick, a graduate of the High School of Art & Design, was born and raised in New York City. His awards include P.S. Art, a citywide competition for pre-K to 12, culminating in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a Seeds of the League Scholarship. Ken’s work focuses on compositional storytelling using the mediums of oils, graphite, watercolors, tattoos, and digital art. His goals include finishing his degree in game development and encouraging others to pursue their art.

description:

Join NYC Parks and New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for this free film!

Hands of Stone

This biopic centers on the legendary Panamanian professional boxer, Roberto Durán (Edgar Ramirez) and his trainer, the iconic, Ray Arcel (Robert De Niro) as he prepares to fight the undefeated lightweight champion, Sugar Ray Leonard (Usher). Written and directed by Venezuelan filmmaker, Jonathan Jakubowicz, this film features also stars Rubén Blades, Ellen Barkin, John Turturro and Jurnee Smollett. Rated R

title: Volunteer Landscaping @ Schmul Park
description:
Date: September 25, 2021

Join the Freshkills Park Alliance and NYC Parks Department for a volunteer day at Schmul Park on September 25. Let's help out at Schmul Park and discover ways to get creative in our green spaces! Learn about native plants, the local pollinators, gardening, and sustainability tips, and help remove invasive species from our pollinator garden.

Register Online

Gear: Wear clothes you don't mind getting dirty, long pants are preferred. Closed-toe shoes like sneakers or boots are required. Please also bring water and sunblock. Gardening gloves will be provided.

Technology: Feel free to take photos, but consider carefully before bringing any electronic devices with you as they may possibly get wet, damaged, or dropped during the program.

Restrictions: You will be asked to sign an activity waiver before participating in the program. Participants must be Ages 14+. Participants under 18 will require a parent or guardian's signature. Waivers will be emailed with confirmation emails closer to the event.

Cancellation: This event will be canceled if registration is too low, or if there is a 60% or greater chance of rain on the day of the event. You will be asked to confirm your registration by email before the event. As we receive cancellations, names will be added from the waitlist. If you know you will be unable to attend, please cancel your registration by emailing info@freshkillspark.org so we can fill the reservation.

COVID-19 Precautions:

This event will follow the current NYC Parks safety guidelines.

Masks, gloves, and hand sanitizer will be available.

By participating in this event you are acknowledging that you and your guests have not experienced a fever, not tested positive for COVID-19, and have not been exposed to anyone with COVID-19 within 14 days of the event. Should you develop symptoms after registration, please cancel your registration by emailing info@freshkillspark.org.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone: (929) 481 2795

Location: Pearson Street and Watson Avenue (in Schmul Park)
location: Pearson Street and Watson Avenue (in Schmul Park)

Cash, credit card and Venmo are accepted, plus Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), Farmers’ Market Nutrition Program (FMNP), and Health Bucks. Wilk Apiaries also pops up on select Saturdays to vend their variety of local and raw honeys.

About Hellgate Farm

Hellgate Farm is a network of residential and rooftop gardens in Queens, NYC. The farm aims to promote urban gardening and a permaculture lifestyle within their local community, providing opportunities for people interested in these practices to connect and learn, as well as share in the abundance of the harvest.

title: Insect Walk With Staten Island Museum
description:
Date: September 25, 2021

As a part of the High Line’s Insectageddon, all-ages are invited to walk and explore the insects that live at Freshkills Park with the Staten Island Museum’s Director of Natural Sciences Colleen Evans and a Freshkills Park biologist. Participants will use nets to catch and learn about insects up close and see what makes Freshkills an ideal habitat!

Insectageddon is a day-long festival featuring site-specific programming at partner sites around the world. Inspired by artist Cecilia Vicuña and culminating the High Line’s month-long horticulture celebration, Insectageddon seeks to both reflect on and raise awareness for our interconnectedness with the insect world.

Transportation: By registering for this event, you confirm you will provide your own transportation. Each ticket admits 1 car, containing up to 5 participants. During registration, you will be asked about additional participants in your car.

Gear: Wear a hat and sturdy shoes that you don’t mind getting wet or muddy. Please also bring water, a snack, and sunblock.

Technology: Feel free to take photos, but consider carefully before bringing any electronic devices with you as they may possibly get wet, damaged, or dropped during the program.

Restrictions: You will be asked to sign an activity waiver before participating in the program.

Cancellation: This tour will be canceled if registration is too low, or if there is a 60% or greater chance of rain on the day of the event. You will be asked to confirm your registration by email before the tour. As we receive cancellations, names will be added from the waitlist. If you know you will be unable to attend, please cancel your registration by emailing info@freshkillspark.org so we can fill the reservation.

COVID-19 Precautions:

You will find current information on NYC Parks safety guidelines here.

Masks, gloves, and hand sanitizer will be available.

By participating in this event you are acknowledging that you and your guests have not experienced a fever, not tested positive for COVID-19, and have not been exposed to anyone with COVID-19 within 14 days of the event. Should you develop symptoms after registration, please cancel your registration by emailing info@freshkillspark.org.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Freshkills Park Event Entrance

title: Camera Obscura at Dyckman Farmhouse Museum
description:
Date: September 25, 2021

Gibson + Recoder: Obscurus Projectum

Across its long history, the camera obscura has been an artistic tool, a philosophical device, a scientific implement. Each function has made the camera obscura an analog of something: the eye, human consciousness, the “outside” world itself (Gibson and Recoder call it “the earliest projection of the world, or simply world projection”). The renewed interest in the camera obscura evidenced by exhibitions like this one, and the persistence with which some filmmakers and critics work to sustain analogue moving image media, are sometimes dismissed as mere nostalgia, or contrariness for its own sake, or fetishism of technologies that have been rendered obsolete by digital. Obscurus Projectum suggests another, deeper, reason for the ongoing appeal of the analogue in the so-called digital millennium: rather than alienating us with a cryptic interior that has no “room” for us, camera obscuras – as models of analogue image-making technology in general – admit us, let us in. They make real space for our bodies rather than a virtual space we cannot inhabit. They are part of the physical world we live in. Analog and digital media both make images, of course, but the former also appeals to our tactile sense, and thus answers our desire for physical connection with our world and with those objects and other bodies with whom we share our rooms. (Jonathan Walley)

This program is made possible by the New York City Artist Corps.

Gibson + Recoder have exhibited their celebrated expanded cinema performances and installations at the Museum Kunstpalast Düsseldorf, M HKA, Serralves Foundation, EYE Film Museum, REDCAT, Mad. Sq. Art, and Ballroom Marfa. Their works are in the permanent collections of the Whitney Museum of American Art, Academy Museum of Motion Pictures, and Memorial Art Gallery. They live and work in New York. www.gibsonrecoder.com

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 2:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 304-9422

title: Central Park Youth Basketball Clinics
description:
Date: September 25, 2021

Enhance your basketball skills through small group instruction and competitive games.

It's not just shooting hoops! Our high-energy, interactive youth basketball clinics cultivate skill development, team play, and sportsmanship both on and off the court. Players aged 6–14 are encouraged to join us on Saturdays and Sundays from July 10 to August 28, 2021. From September 11 to October 30, 2021, clinics will be held on Saturdays only. FREE and open to players of all levels. On-site registration each day on a first-come, first-served basis.

Ages 6–10
11:00 a.m. – 11:30 a.m.: Check In
11:30 a.m. – 12:30 p.m.: Basketball Clinic

Ages 11–14
12:30 p.m. – 1:00 p.m.: Check In
1:00 p.m. – 2:30 p.m.: Basketball Clinic

In case of inclement weather, call (347) 443-0656 to confirm cancellation on the day.

COVID-19 HEALTH AND SAFETY POLICIES

Ensuring the health and safety of our guests, staff, and the public is our top priority. Central Park Conservancy programs follow recommended guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, New York State, and New York City and have adopted enhanced cleaning procedures to ensure a safe playing environment.

This year’s Youth Basketball Clinics ask unvaccinated players to:

  • wear face masks that completely cover their nose and mouth for the duration of the program.
  • complete an on-site health assessment and temperature check prior to playing.

Regardless of vaccination status, all players should continue to monitor themselves for COVID-19 symptoms and stay home if they feel unwell.

Read about policies related to COVID-19, inclement weather, and more on our Frequently Asked Questions page.

Please fill out the Health Assessment form prior to attending the program.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 2:30 pm

Contact phone: (347) 443-0656

description:
Date: September 25, 2021

Join The New York Botanical Garden (NYBG) Bronx Green-Up at Bissel Gardens on Saturday, September 25 for the last tour of the season. Meet at The Propagation Area at Barnes and Bruner Avenues. The tour will be led by Bissel member Heather Warren-Dombrowa, who will introduce you to the various gardens and persons that make up this green oasis. Then, go for a stroll to their Farmers Market to enjoy a healthy cooking demonstration by B. Blossom Catering and health screenings by Montefiore.

To meet us at any of the sites, RSVP on the NYBG website for the schedule.

All attendees must follow social distancing guidelines. Face coverings are required for all attendees, regardless of vaccination status.

This event is in collaboration with B. Blossom, Bronx Tourism Council, Bissel Gardens, La Familia Verde, Mary Mitchell Family and Youth Center, Montefiore Health System, NYC Parks GreenThumb, and the Office of the Bronx Borough President.

description:
Date: September 25, 2021

The performance draws from Michael Hearst’s highly successful series of books, albums, and PBS series. It is an unusually geeky musical presentation of some of the most bizarre animals that roam the planet, odd and daring characters, strange structures, and vehicles as loopy as ostrich-drawn wagons.

Featuring Allyssa Lamb: accordion/vocals, Dylan Thurston: drums, Taylor Bergren-Chrisman: bass, Ben Holmes: trumpet, and Michael Hearst: guitar, claviola, theremin, vocals.

All ages and abilities are welcome. We will ride roughly 4-6 miles at a conversational pace, primarily on bike and pedestrian paths.

This is a free event, but registration is requested.

title: Little Hell Gate Saltmarsh Tour
description:
Date: September 25, 2021

Randall’s Island Park is host to many acres of gorgeous wetland habitat, including a five-acre Little Hell Gate Salt Marsh and one of the city’s only freshwater wetlands. Participants can enjoy viewing beautiful wildflowers, birds, and other native wildlife while learning about some of the fascinating history that has shaped the natural areas on the Island. Meet snowy egrets, yellow-crowned night herons, red-tailed hawks, and more!

Start time: 2:00 pm

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 860-1899

title: Mark Morris Dance Group in Brooklyn Bridge Park
description:
Date: September 25, 2021

Experience Mark Morris Dance Group (MMDG) in Brooklyn Bridge Park on Saturday, September 25 at Pier 1 Harbor View Lawn! Part of Brooklyn Bridge Park Conservancy’s “Share the Stage” series, MMDG will present a special, outdoor performance (two showings, 2:00 p.m. - 2:45 p.m. and 4:00 p.m. - 4:45pm) and an all-ages family-friendly workshop (3:00 p.m. - 3:45 p.m.). The program features three dance pieces — Quad, Words, and the premiere of their brand new performance Water — under a stunning backdrop of the Manhattan skyline, at one of the Park’s most iconic locations.

This event is free and open to the public. No advanced registration required.

Please note this event is subject to change due to weather or other circumstances. Check the Brooklyn Bridge Park website for the most up-to-date information regarding this event.

title: Nature Walk: Butterflies in the Garden
description:
Date: September 25, 2021

Monarch butterflies are one of the few insects that migrate south to warmer climates for the winter, and they’ll be passing through the Bronx in September. Join naturalists and butterfly enthusiasts Paul Keim and Pam Golben on a quest to see monarchs and other late-season butterfly species in the gardens of Wave Hill.

Ages 10 and older welcome with an adult.

Space is limited. Registration is required onsite on the day of the walk at the Perkins Visitor Center.

Questions? Please email us at information@wavehill.org or call (718) 549-3200 ext. 251.

Wings over Wave Hill: Butterfly Day event.

End time: 3:00 pm

September 26 – FRENCH COOKIN’ BLUES - David “Doc” French, Leader - This Blues Hall of Fame band plays authentic New York Blues derived from the Delta to Chicago, Texas and Louisiana, and our own great city.

Come join us for these sweet Sundays in the park!

title: Leaning Into Death: A Brooklyn Book Festival Bookend Event
description:
Date: September 26, 2021

A virtual conversation about changing the way we think about the end of life and some books that are informing this change.

David R. Roth, author of "The Femme Fatale Hypothesis" (coming soon), speaks with RN and Master of Divinity student Marcy Tardio and End-of-Life Midwife Martha Roth-Irwin about death as our final act of life. The premise: Given the privilege, we have an obligation to our loved ones and ourselves to honor our lives with the way we approach our deaths.

Please register via Eventbrite, everyone who registers will receive the Zoom meeting information on September 25.

title: LuLu LoLo Productions Presents: Dante, Opera, and Shining Shoes: Rituals of My Italian Immigrant Grandpa's Life
description:
Date: September 26, 2021

Performance and visual artist playwright/actor LuLu LoLo brings to life memories of her Italian immigrant grandfather Giovanni Pascale who died before she was born. Through family lore, he was a man of myth to her. Grandpa Giovanni loved opera, the poetry of Dante, and shined shoes for a living.

This performance celebrates his life with operatic arias and accordion performed by tenor, Aaron Halevy; and with poet Angelo Zeolla reciting in both Italian and English an excerpt from Dante Alighieri’s La Divina Commedia (commemorating the 700th anniversary of Dante’s death September 14, 1321). Dancers Sara Grassi, Maria Hochnowski, and Rathi Varma will highlight his story of immigration and shining shoes (choreographed by Anabella Lenzu with musical accompaniment by Aaron Halevy). The struggle of the immigrants of the past is the struggle of the immigrants of today.

Performed in the shadow of Dante Alighieri’s statue and the Metropolitan Opera House at Dante Park, Columbus Avenue at 63rd Street.

  • First Performance: Sunday, September 19, 2021: 2:30 p.m. - 3:00 p.m.
  • Second Performance: Sunday, September 19, 2021: 4:00 p.m. - 4:30 p.m.

Rain date: Sunday, September 26, 2021.

Seating is limited

This program is made possible by the City Artist Corps Grants program, presented by The New York Foundation for the Arts (NYFA) and the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs (DCLA), with support from the Mayor’s Office of Media and Entertainment (MOME) as well as Queens Theatre.

Start time: 2:30 pm

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Columbus Avenue at 63rd Street (in Dante Park)

title: Metropolitan Opera: Livestream Premiere of Terence Blanchard’s Fire Shut Up in My Bones
description:
Date: September 27, 2021

The Metropolitan Opera opens its 2021–22 season on September 27 with the Met premiere of Terence Blanchard’s Fire Shut Up in My Bones, the first work by a Black composer to be presented at the Met. Based on Charles M. Blow’s moving memoir of the same name and featuring a libretto by Kasi Lemmons, this new staging is co-directed by James Robinson and Camille A. Brown. Brown, who is also the production’s choreographer, becomes the first Black director to create a mainstage Met production. Music Director Yannick Nézet-Séguin conducts the cast starring Will Liverman as Charles, Angel Blue as Destiny/Loneliness/Greta, and Latonia Moore as Billie.

Fire Shut Up in My Bones tells a poignant and profound story about a young man’s journey to overcome a lifetime of trauma and hardship. The opera follows Charles through his adolescence and ultimately leads to a fateful moment: when he must decide whether to break free from his trauma and begin to rebuild his life.

The open-air amphitheater opens to the public at 4:30 p.m., and seats will be available on a first-come, first-served basis. All guests must provide proof of full vaccination against Covid-19 or a negative Covid-19 PCR test administered within 72 hours prior to entry. The Marcus Garvey Park presentation is supported by The Ford Foundation.

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 8:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: The Marcus Garvey Park Amphitheater (in Marcus Garvey Park)

title: Watercolor Workshops
description:
Date: September 28, 2021

Join us for a watercolor painting workshop series in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Kenneth Fitzpatrick will teach you how to draw and paint using nature as your inspiration. Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.For your comfort, bring a mat or chair.About the artist:Kenneth Fitzpatrick, a graduate of the High School of Art & Design, was born and raised in New York City. His awards include P.S. Art, a citywide competition for pre-K to 12, culminating in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a Seeds of the League Scholarship. Ken’s work focuses on compositional storytelling using the mediums of oils, graphite, watercolors, tattoos, and digital art. His goals include finishing his degree in game development and encouraging others to pursue their art.

Park staff will be available for tours and questions during the duration of open hours. If you can't make it to Pier 40, we will also be live streaming feeding and/or species spotlights each day on Facebook live @hudsonriverpark.

Animals are released each season to ensure that their behaviors and life cycles are minimally impacted.

Please make sure to bring a mask if you are attending in person.

title: Summer on the Hudson: Moving For Life
description:
Date: September 28, 2021

Moving for Life is a gentle work out that begins with breathing exercises, then moves into active aerobic dancing that strengthens body awareness.

Pre-registration for the event is required. Management reserves the right to cap participation in accordance with current COVID-19 outdoor safety guidelines.

Please register online.

Please note: We are offering outdoor programs with limited attendance so that you can have a safe and enjoyable time in parks. Based on New York State guidance for outdoor events during COVID-19, we’ve put protocols into place to keep our participants and staff safe and healthy. We're asking everyone to help us stay safe.

Know Before You Go:

For everyone's safety, we are asking all participants to observe the following guidelines:

  • Please wear a mask if you are unvaccinated, or if it makes you feel more comfortable
  • All individuals should maintain social distancing of six feet during programming, regardless of vaccination status
  • Please wear a mask if social distancing cannot be maintained
  • Wash your hands before attending a program
  • Stay home if you are sick

Additionally, we encourage participants to bring their own hand sanitizer to our programs.

Start time: 6:30 pm

End time: 7:30 pm

Contact phone: (212) 870-3070

Location: Pier I (in Riverside Park South)

Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. About the artist:Kalila Abdur-Razzaq was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. She recently graduated Purchase College with a concentration in painting and a minor in Art History. Her preferred mediums are oil, watercolor, and silkscreen. As of 2021, Abdur-Razzaq is included in three permanent installations. The most recent is a commission by The Colored Girls Museum of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Please register online.

title: River Project: Live From the Field
description:
Date: September 30, 2021

Wildlife thrives all over NYC, especially in HRPK's waters! Tune into @HudsonRiverPark's Instagram Live for an insider’s look into the Park's Estuarine Sanctuary as we study environmental DNA, analyze microplastics, sample fish populations and so much more!

HRPK's River Project conducts research and offers hands-on environmental education and scientific programming with the purpose of communicating the ecological importance of the Park’s 400-acre Estuarine Sanctuary. Dedicated to community engagement, stewardship and learning, the River Project offers at-home STEM activities, tours of marine-biology stations and other educational resources to support scientific understanding of the Lower Hudson Estuary.

Start time: 2:00 pm

End time: 2:30 pm

Contact phone: (212) 627-2020

description:

Animals are released each season to ensure that their behaviors and life cycles are minimally impacted.

title: Watercolor Workshops
description:
Date: September 30, 2021

Join us for a watercolor painting workshop series in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Kenneth Fitzpatrick will teach you how to draw and paint using nature as your inspiration. Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.For your comfort, bring a mat or chair.About the artist: Kenneth Fitzpatrick, a graduate of the High School of Art & Design, was born and raised in New York City. His awards include P.S. Art, a citywide competition for pre-K to 12, culminating in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a Seeds of the League Scholarship. Ken’s work focuses on compositional storytelling using the mediums of oils, graphite, watercolors, tattoos, and digital art. His goals include finishing his degree in game development and encouraging others to pursue their art.

Start time: 4:00 pm

End time: 6:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: DeMatti Park Fieldhouse (in De Matti Park)

title: (RESCHEDULED) Joyce Manor: Celebrating 10 Years of Their Self-Titled Debut / Turnover / Prince Daddy & The Hyena
description:
Date: September 30, 2021

Update (9/22): Due to the likelihood of inclement weather expected, Capital One City Parks Foundation SummerStage has postponed the Joyce Manor / Turnover / Tigers Jaw / Prince Daddy & The Hyena show scheduled for Thursday, September 23 at 6 PM in Central Park.

The show has been rescheduled for Thursday, September 30 at 6 PM (please note: unfortunately, Tigers Jaw will not be performing on this new date).

All previously purchased tickets will be honored at the new date. Refunds are available upon request.

For any concerns or inquiries, please contact boxoffice@cityparksfoundation.org

--

Please note: In response to the increasing spread of the COVID-19 Delta variant, SummerStage now requires all guests to show proof of full vaccination, along with government issued ID, in order to gain entry to our shows.

In order to attend Joyce Manor, guests are required to have had their final dosage of the vaccine by September 9.

In addition, masks are required upon entry to the venue and strongly encouraged for all guests for the duration of the performance, as is physical distance. More information on acceptable documentation, mask guidelines, and other safety protocols can be found here.

—

Tickets: $25 Advance / $35 Day of Show

—

Torrance, California’s Joyce Manor broke out in 2011 with their self-titled debut LP, propelled out of the SoCal basement scene and into the hearts of hardcore kids, emos, and pop-punkers across the country. Ten years, five albums, four splits, three EPs, and two compilations later, they’ve become standard-bearers for a new generation of emotionally adept pop-punk bands that have cleansed the word emo from its pejorative connotations. For SummerStage, they’re joined in celebrating their debut’s 10th anniversary by their East-Coast emo peers Turnover (Virginia), Tigers Jaw (Philadelphia), and Prince Daddy & The Hyena (Albany, NY) for a showcase of some of the various micro scenes of emo’s 4th wave.

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 10:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Rumsey Playfield (in Central Park)

title: Movies Under the Stars: Brighton Beach Memoirs
description:
Date: September 30, 2021

Join NYC Parks and New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for this free film!

Brighton Beach Memoirs

This classic 1986 Neil Simon coming-of-age comedy follows Eugene Jerome, a Jewish teen as he navigates puberty, sexual awakening, and a search for identity as he tries to deal with his loving, but overwhelming family. Set in Brighton Beach in the 1930s and based on the Simon’s semi-autobiographical Broadway play, this delightful film stars Jonathan Silverman, Blythe Danner, Judith Ivey and other Broadway notables. Rated PG-13.

Know Before You Go
You should come arrive 6:40 p.m. to get your spot for the movie. Please bring your own picnic blanket or chair. Food is OK, but no alcohol or smoking is permitted. All are welcome!

For everyone's safety, we are asking all participants to observe the following guidelines:

  • Please wear a mask if you are unvaccinated, or if it makes you feel more comfortable
  • All individuals should maintain social distancing of six feet during programming, regardless of vaccination status
  • Please wear a mask if social distancing cannot be maintained
  • Wash your hands before attending a program
  • Stay home if you are sick

Please refer to the NY State Department of Health's website for updates and CDC's guidance on large gatherings regarding COVID-19 restrictions.

Contact (212) 360-1430 or accessibility@parks.nyc.gov for more information regarding accessibility.

Start time: 6:40 pm

End time: 8:30 pm

Contact phone: 718-965-8942

Location: Brighton Beach Playground (in Brighton Playground)
categories: Film | Free Summer Movies | Seniors | Movies Under the Stars

title: Movies Under the Stars: Captain Marvel
description:
Date: September 30, 2021

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film!

Carol Danvers becomes one of the universe's most powerful heroes when Earth is caught in the middle of a galactic war between two alien races. Rated PG-13.

Grab a blanket and come enjoy a movie in a neighborhood park or playground! This summer, NYC Parks will host family-friendly movie showings across the five boroughs. Movies begin at dusk. You should arrive before 7:00 p.m. to get your spot. This event is FREE and open to the public, but seating is limited. Reservations are not taken.

Know Before You Go:

For everyone's safety, we are asking all participants to observe the following guidelines:

  • All individuals should maintain social distancing of six feet during programming, regardless of vaccination status

Glass bottles and alcoholic beverages are strictly prohibited.

This movie is sponsored by Speaker Corey Johnson

title: Coexisting with Raccoons
description:

New York City's raccoons share a lot in common with the average New Yorker. They're adaptable, resourceful, and always know where to find a good meal. It will share information about the basic behavior and biology of raccoons and provide tips for coexistence.

The presentation will be in English with live captions. It is geared towards adults, but all are welcome.

title: (RESCHEDULED) Yo La Tengo / Mountain Movers / DJ Amanda Nazario
description:
Date: October 1, 2021

Update (8/31): Due to the likelihood of severe weather, Capital One City Parks Foundation SummerStage has rescheduled this show for Friday, October 1.

--

Tickets are no longer required for free performances at SummerStage. All free performances will be open to the public, first come, first served, with limited capacity, and will continue to follow CDC recommendations. Visit here for more information.

New Jersey institution Yo La Tengo have been critical darlings since shortly after their formation in 1984. Over four decades, they have continually experimented with new ideas— unafraid to reimagine their sound from record to record across their 16-album discography. A mainstay of the New York City rock scene, they come to SummerStage with nothing to prove, but also years of experience in pleasing crowds, whether with original fan-favorites or cover songs by request.

Start time: 5:00 pm

End time: 10:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Rumsey Playfield (in Central Park)

title: Highbridge Film Festival: Selena
description:
Date: October 1, 2021

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film!

Selena

The true story of Selena, a Texas-born Tejano singer who rose from cult status to performing at the Astrodome, as well as having chart-topping albums on the Latin music charts. PG

Grab a blanket and snuggle up for this year’s Fall Film Festival at Highbridge Pool Deck. NYC Parks will host a series of movie screenings accompanied by fun and exciting activities fit for the whole family.

Check what will happen on Fridays

September 24, 2021

5:30 p.m. // Scavenger Hunt

7:00 p.m. // Dora and the Last City of Gold

October 1, 2021

6:00 p.m. // Dance Cardio Class

7:00 p.m. // Selena

October 8, 2021

6:00 p.m. // Arts & Crafts

7:00 p.m. // Coco

October 15, 2021

4:00 p.m. // Block Party

7:00 p.m. // In the Heights

For everyone's safety, we are asking all participants to observe the following guidelines:

  • Please wear a mask if you are unvaccinated, or if it makes you feel more comfortable
  • All individuals should maintain social distancing of six feet during programming, regardless of vaccination status
  • Please wear a mask if social distancing cannot be maintained
  • Wash your hands before attending a program
  • Stay home if you are sick

Glass bottles and alcoholic beverages are strictly prohibited.

description:

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film!

Infinity War

The Avengers and their allies must be willing to sacrifice all in an attempt to defeat the powerful Thanos before his blitz of devastation and ruin puts an end to the universe. Rated PG-13.

Grab a blanket and come enjoy a movie in a neighborhood park or playground! This summer, NYC Parks will host family-friendly movie showings across the five boroughs. Movies begin at dusk. You should arrive before 7:00 p.m. to get your spot. This event is FREE and open to the public, but seating is limited. Reservations are not taken.

Date: October 2, 2021

Start the weekend off right with stunning riverfront views and a refreshing Pilates workout in HRPK. Brought to you by Chelsea Piers Fitness, this Healthy on the Hudson class aims to improve flexibility, core strength, body awareness and muscle tone with low-impact exercises. Join us every Saturday at 9:30 AM along the sparkling Hudson River waterfront.

This program is adaptable to all experience levels to help keep you Healthy on the Hudson.

To register for this free class, visit HRPK's website. Please sign up early, as space is limited.

Please bring a mat!

End time: 10:30 am

Contact phone: (212) 627-2020

title: Hellgate Farm Stand
description:
Date: October 2, 2021

Every Saturday at Socrates in the spring, summer, fall, Hellgate Farm offers fresh seasonal local produce and small batch goods, like their signature hot sauce. Cash, credit card and Venmo are accepted, plus Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), Farmers’ Market Nutrition Program (FMNP), and Health Bucks. Wilk Apiaries also pops up on select Saturdays to vend their variety of local and raw honeys.

About Hellgate Farm

Hellgate Farm is a network of residential and rooftop gardens in Queens, NYC. The farm aims to promote urban gardening and a permaculture lifestyle within their local community, providing opportunities for people interested in these practices to connect and learn, as well as share in the abundance of the harvest.

End time: 2:00 pm

title: Exhibit: The Perfect Sea Mural
description:

Members of the South Shore Artists Group created an engaging and interactive mural entitled "The Perfect Sea" to educate children and adults about the sea and its ecology; in particular, how pollution affects sea life in our local waters.

The exhibition will be on display at the Lenape Gallery at the Conference House Park Visitors Center through the end of the year.

Free admission.

All current COVID-19 protocols to be followed

description:
Date: October 2, 2021

Explore a bit of Staten Island's past and history.

The Fire and Tide exhibition explores the history of the former turn of the century Terra Marine Inn. This hotel was a wonderful piece of Staten Island gilded past. The exhibit combines history and original artwork focusing on the bygone location.

Free admission. Exhibit on display through December.

All COVID-19 protocols to be followed.

title: Forest Management Morning in Forest Park
description:
Date: October 2, 2021

Build your nature skills while caring for the woods with community members. The Natural Areas Conservancy and Forest Park Trust are teaming up to restore the woodlands in Forest Park this fall. We would love for you to join us to help remove invasive species in preparation for a native forest planting event in October! This in-person event is open to all, and is part of an ongoing effort to increase the health of Forest Park.

Registration is required to attend.

Please wear sturdy, closed-toe shoes and dress for the weather. Bring water and a snack if you wish. Appropriate for adults, and older supervised children. We will be working in a forested section of the park using hand tools.

title: It's My Park at Lemon Creek Park
description:
Date: October 2, 2021

Please join us along with the National Resources Protective Association, the American Association of Zookeepers at the Staten Island Zoo, and Engines for Change for the Lemon Creek Beach Cleanup in Staten Island! Lemon Creek is one of New York City's last remaining ground-level creeks. Located on the South Shore, its salt marsh and beach area provide a refuge for migrating birds and wetlands flora and fauna. Please wear sunscreen and bring plenty of water to stay hydrated. DON'T FORGET TO WEAR YOUR MASK!

Please register ahead of time at https://www.eventbrite.com/e/lemon-creek-beach-cleanup-tickets-165905861899.

title: Central Park Youth Basketball Clinics
description:
Date: October 2, 2021

Enhance your basketball skills through small group instruction and competitive games.

It's not just shooting hoops! Our high-energy, interactive youth basketball clinics cultivate skill development, team play, and sportsmanship both on and off the court. Players aged 6–14 are encouraged to join us on Saturdays and Sundays from July 10 to August 28, 2021. From September 11 to October 30, 2021, clinics will be held on Saturdays only. FREE and open to players of all levels. On-site registration each day on a first-come, first-served basis.

Ages 6–10
11:00 a.m. – 11:30 a.m.: Check In
11:30 a.m. – 12:30 p.m.: Basketball Clinic

Ages 11–14
12:30 p.m. – 1:00 p.m.: Check In
1:00 p.m. – 2:30 p.m.: Basketball Clinic

In case of inclement weather, call (347) 443-0656 to confirm cancellation on the day.

COVID-19 HEALTH AND SAFETY POLICIES

Ensuring the health and safety of our guests, staff, and the public is our top priority. Central Park Conservancy programs follow recommended guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, New York State, and New York City and have adopted enhanced cleaning procedures to ensure a safe playing environment.

This year’s Youth Basketball Clinics ask unvaccinated players to:

  • wear face masks that completely cover their nose and mouth for the duration of the program.
  • complete an on-site health assessment and temperature check prior to playing.

Regardless of vaccination status, all players should continue to monitor themselves for COVID-19 symptoms and stay home if they feel unwell.

Read about policies related to COVID-19, inclement weather, and more on our Frequently Asked Questions page.

Please fill out the Health Assessment form prior to attending the program.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 2:30 pm

Contact phone: (347) 443-0656

Location: North Meadow Recreation Center (in Central Park)

title: D.O.T.S Presents: Kenny Beats & Friends
description:
Date: October 2, 2021

Please note: In response to the increasing spread of the COVID-19 Delta variant, SummerStage now requires all guests to show proof of full vaccination, along with government issued ID, in order to gain entry to our shows.

In order to attend D.O.T.S Presents: Kenny Beats & Friends, guests are required to have had their final dosage of the vaccine by September 18.

In addition, masks are required upon entry to the venue and strongly encouraged for all guests for the duration of the performance, as is physical distance. More information on acceptable documentation, mask guidelines, and other safety protocols can be found here.

—

Tickets:

$20 Advance / $25 Day of Show

—

Kenny Beats is a multi-platinum music producer, artist and DJ. Over the last few years, he has produced critically acclaimed albums for Vince Staples, Denzel Curry, Rico Nasty and Key!. In addition, he has produced chart topping singles with Ski Mask the Slump God, Lil Baby, Skrillex, Gucci Mane, FKA Twigs, Future, Freddie Gibbs, and many more. Outside of his productions, Kenny Beats is also the creator of the hit YouTube series “The Cave” which has amassed over 50M views and hosted artists such as Thundercat, Mac DeMarco, Doja Cat, 6lack, Danny Brown, Denzel Curry, and many more. By hosting weekly Beat Battles and educating young artists through his Twitch platform, Kenny has created one of the largest music communities on Twitch and the second largest music community in the world on Discord.

He’ll be joined by special guests Kenny Mason, Teezo Touchdown, Zach Fox and more for this unforgettable evening at Capital One City Parks Foundation SummerStage.

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 10:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Rumsey Playfield (in Central Park)

title: Movies Under the Stars: Yesterday
description:
Date: October 2, 2021

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film!

Yesterday

A struggling musician realizes he's the only person on Earth who can remember The Beatles after waking up in an alternate timeline where they never existed. Rated PG-13.

Grab a blanket and come enjoy a movie in a neighborhood park or playground! This summer, NYC Parks will host family-friendly movie showings across the five boroughs. Movies begin at dusk. You should arrive before 7:00 p.m. to get your spot. This event is FREE and open to the public, but seating is limited. Reservations are not taken.

title: Summer on the Hudson: Overlook Concerts
description:
Date: October 3, 2021

Riverside Park Conservancy and our generous supporters present our Fall 2021 Overlook Concert series, with talent from French Cookin’ Blues, the James “Pony” Kerr Trio, and the Manhattan School of Music Community Partnerships.

September 26 – FRENCH COOKIN’ BLUES - David “Doc” French, Leader - This Blues Hall of Fame band plays authentic New York Blues derived from the Delta to Chicago, Texas and Louisiana, and our own great city.

October 3 – THE JAMES “PONY” KERR TRIO - A wonderful mix of Bluegrass and Delta Blues, this band brings a new sound to our series.

October 10 – MANHATTAN SCHOOL OF MUSIC JAZZ COMBO - The great jazz standards played by a group of talented jazz musicians

Come join us for these sweet Sundays in the park!

Know Before You Go:

title: Exhibit: The Perfect Sea Mural
description:
Date: October 5, 2021

Members of the South Shore Artists Group created an engaging and interactive mural entitled "The Perfect Sea" to educate children and adults about the sea and its ecology; in particular, how pollution affects sea life in our local waters.

The exhibition will be on display at the Lenape Gallery at the Conference House Park Visitors Center through the end of the year.

Free admission.

All current COVID-19 protocols to be followed

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

title: Exhibit: Fire and Tide - Terra Marine Inn: A Brief History of Huguenot Park, Staten Island
description:
Date: October 5, 2021

Explore a bit of Staten Island's past and history.

The Fire and Tide exhibition explores the history of the former turn of the century Terra Marine Inn. This hotel was a wonderful piece of Staten Island gilded past. The exhibit combines history and original artwork focusing on the bygone location.

Free admission. Exhibit on display through December.

All COVID-19 protocols to be followed.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (917) 417-6817

Location: Conference House Park Visitor Center (in Conference House Park)

title: Fall Volunteer Days at the Bronx River Foodway
description:
Date: October 5, 2021

Lend a hand and connect with community and friends during our upcoming First Saturdays at the Foodway programming! Support morning stewardship, which includes gardening and beautifying of New York City's only edible food forest. Join us as well for some tours around our food forest, where we discuss the value of these herbs and veggies for both our health and the environment.

Hand sanitizer, masks, gloves, social distancing guidelines, and temperature checks provided to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

Thank you for being interested in volunteering with the Bronx River Alliance. You are committing to a special effort during a special time.

Please review the NYC Guidelines for Volunteering in Parks during COVID:

  • Stay home if sick (e.g., running a fever, coughing, experiencing loss of taste or smell, or other Covid-19 symptoms)
  • Maintain 6 feet of distance
  • Wash hands and clean surfaces frequently
  • Wear face coverings

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 542-4284

Location: Concrete Plant Park

Our flow-through aquarium houses dozens of species of fish and invertebrates all caught within the Park as part of an ongoing ecological survey. Park staff will be available for tours and questions during the duration of open hours. If you can't make it to Pier 40, we will also be live streaming feeding and/or species spotlights each day on Facebook live @hudsonriverpark.

Animals are released each season to ensure that their behaviors and life cycles are minimally impacted.

Please make sure to bring a mask if you are attending in person.

Start time: 3:00 pm

End time: 6:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 627-2020

title: It's My Park at Chief Dennis L. Devlin Park
description:
Date: October 6, 2021

Join Loving the Bronx as they honor Chief Dennis Devlin and all who perished on 9/11. The group will do a general clean up and plant daffodil bulbs in the green spaces within the park, as well as in the tree beds that surround the park perimeter. This year they will also be honoring local neighbor, Peter Doherty, who was born, raised, and lived in a house across the street from the park his entire life. He was our point person, our eyes on the street, when it came to any issues at the park.

title: River Project: Diversity Digest
description:
Date: October 6, 2021

During Diversity Digest, you'll learn what it means to be a naturalist, cataloging local wildlife with the free iNaturalist app throughout the week and then sharing your observations with the HRPK community. Together, we'll congratulate those who made the most observations and highlight some of our favorite images. You’ll also get a chance to ask Park staff questions!

HRPK's River Project conducts research and offers hands-on environmental education and scientific programming with the purpose of communicating the ecological importance of the Park’s 400-acre Estuarine Sanctuary. Dedicated to community engagement, stewardship and learning, the River Project offers at-home STEM activities, tours of marine-biology stations and other educational resources to support scientific understanding of the Lower Hudson Estuary.

Join us on Facebook live @HudsonRiverPark. If you are a teacher or educator and would like to have your class join via Zoom, please contact education@hrpt.ny.gov.

Start time: 12:00 pm
